messages.text: When setting up tests and you'd like to test some of the functions that exist in the userspace when using `Requires.jl`, is there a way to `add` and `using` the `Requires`'d packages without those packages being added to the project or manifest tomls? In other words, is there a way to temporarily add them for the sake of testing?

elements.text: When setting up tests and you'd like to test some of the functions that exist in the userspace when using
'd packages without those packages being added to the project or manifest tomls? In other words, is there a way to temporarily add them for the sake of testing?

messages.text: I recently encountered an error message on my Travis-CI page on one of my public Julia packages : "Builds have been temporarily disabled for public repositories due to a negative credit balance." I was wondering if anybody knows if I can have a free Travis account that works for public (open source) packages. I can't really afford the monthly fee for the subscription Travis account.

elements.text: I recently encountered an error message on my Travis-CI page on one of my public Julia packages : "Builds have been temporarily disabled for public repositories due to a negative credit balance." I was wondering if anybody knows if I can have a free Travis account that works for public (open source) packages. I can't really afford the monthly fee for the subscription Travis account.

messages.text:
When writing software to deal with data that is bigger than memory (30gb+ - 200gb) is the standard to rely on virtual memory (assuming a good preforming SSD) or process the data in chunks then merge at the end?

I’m assuming there’s multiple opinions on this topic. I couldn’t find much information online.

Heres how I see it from my opinion, please correct me if Im wrong.

Virtual memory:
• Easier to implement
• Great when additional memory needed is not too big
• Hardware dependent
• Doesn’t preform well on really big data?
• Not possible on docker??
Chunking:
• More lines of code, more things can go wrong.
• Not as hardware dependent
• Preforms better on really big data?

messages.text: Is there a standard way to determine whether you're in a CI run? Something like `parse(Bool, lowercase(get(ENV, "CI", "false")))`?
